job_title: Data Supervisor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: job stability; acceptable pay; a healthy amount of business
cons:
UPS is a logistics company, but my center is a disorganized mess. My center manager cannot seem to get past tending to sudden emergencies and last-minuted deadlines. He's way overworked, and doesn't have time to ensure new hires get proper training.

The other supervisors explained to me that his regional manager yells at him and threatens him a lot. He's held accountable for our center's performance, but not given the authority to execute on it and run his center. From what I'm told, he actually can't fire drivers for poor performance -- only for safety violations. The drivers seem to be be unhealthily comfortable, some working slow just to get overtime pay. An this behavior seems to be protected by a very strong driver's union. Complaining is rampant among drivers, and not the constructive, civil kind. There is more man drama here than I ever expected to be exposed to in a professional atmosphere.

Communication and Respect seem to be poor, even among managers. I am told by the shop steward (the driver's union mediator of conflicts) that all of the onroad supervisors in our center have blocked each other's cell phone numbers. I have not confirmed this, but I believe it. I saw more than a few heated and disrespectful conflicts between supervisors. 

My own supervisor was condescending with me for my first 8 months there, and when I finally confronted him about it, he wouldn't admit he had been disrespectful. He just switched offices and stopped talking to me. I talked to HR about it, and they didn't try to help. They just tried to see if they could punish him, and said they couldn't unless he had cussed at me. Thankfully (?), my supervisor recently got promoted to onroad supervisor, so I don't work with him anymore.

As an office worker, my daily work involves using software that is outdated by 15+ years to perform menial data corrections that could easily be automated.

review_title: Good culture incoming but true colors revealed
job_title: Customer Solutions Supervisor in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- Flexibility: organization had started to embrace periodic work from home prior to COVID and work-life balance was improved

- Benefits: health benefits used to allow spouse regardless of employment status but still more affordable compared to other employers; dental and vision were fine; optional legal benefits were invaluable

- Opportunities for growth: there are many different roles in different practices so lateral moves and moves into different groups (ie sales to engineer) were common as observed

- Self-development resources: has a system similar to  LinkedIn Learning (not the best but sufficient) and digital access to technical learning manuals

- Networking: there are a lot of smart people to learn from at the peer level
cons:
- Leadership: very passive management, no active engagement, periodic performance reviews focused more on failures rather than successes, unorganized when it comes to passing pertinent updates from HR (some groups get information ahead of others)

- Compensation: company performance based bonus is heavily tied to factors out of many groups control and often attributed to a unionized labor force; for many of the positions that aren’t IT, UPS well below the market for salaries

- Talent Management: a lackluster system that glitches and inhibits easy navigation to set and track goals as well as conducting employee reviews

- Nepotism/Favoritism: multiple generations of employees exist within the company and are provide obvious paths for success; there is no chance for advancement if a manager has a close working relationship with another employee and mentorship programs are just lip service and a considered a chore for the involved mentors

- Advancement: for a company that was admired for policies to hire within, UPS has disregarded current employees with deep company experience and knowledge for young, outside talent. Although pathways are documented for employee development and success, utilization is not realized OR audited

- Internal work collaboration: getting information for work is hard as well as getting new tools procured to improve current processes. IT control silos are a heavy barrier to getting access to necessary data or approval to onboard INDUSTRY tools not used by the company

review_title: The bads outweigh the goods due to managment
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great pay, amazing benefits (Vacation, health insurance, etc)
cons: I can only review based off the San Antonio Preload, but i will tell you that management has gotten worse and worse over my 2 years with the company. Nothing happens to the bad employees and its always the good ones that end up being forced to do their work for them so the bad employees purposely slack off(To include, taking their time, showing up 15-45 min late every single day with no repercussions) because they know they are going to get their job done for them. I've seen The managers get in loaders face and yell at the good employees for not doing the bad employees work for them. There is no reward for doing a "good job". In the 2 years ive been there, I cant recall a time where i was given a simple "Thank you" for working hard. The Senior management degrades and screams at part time and full time sups to the point of tears on a daily basis which is then directed to the hourly employees through their frustration. If you're a female or gay, be cautious, sexual harassment is a very big issue here from both the hourly employees and Sups. The overall morale is low. If you get injured, they beg you to not file an injury report and want you to "Give it a few days" then when you come back they will tell you its to late to file a report. Most people are miserable and dread coming to work every day. Along with this, they are SO unorganized. How can we get an envelope from here to Germany in 24 hours but we "loose" Trailers in our own yard that ends up getting pushed out 10 min from when the drivers are leaving and now we have a thousand packages that arent getting delivered so we end up having more work the next day. I used to love my job and come in with a smile every day. Due to these reasons, i can't care for it anymore.
